DOC.brief_summary: Under the hypothesis that dexmedetomidine sedation would result in less upper airway obstruction, we evaluated the occurrence of upper airway collapse or the requirement of airway intervention in patients with obstructive sleep apnea during dexmedetomidine or propofol sedation.
DOC.criteria: Surgery under spinal anesthesia Intraoperative sedation American Society of Anesthesiology physical status 1 or 2 Apnea/hypopnea index ≥ 5/h in WatchPAT 200 analysis Anatomical defects on upper respiratory tract Psychotic disorder Drug addition Alcohol addition body mass index ≥ 35 kg/m2
